Project Description  The Baipaza landslide in southern Tajikistan blocked the Vakhsh 
River following an earthquake on 3 March 2002. This earthquake 
had  its  epicenter  in  neighboring  Afghanistan  with  a  recorded 
magnitude  of  7.4  on  the  Richter  scale.  Initially,  the  landslide 
blocked the narrow waterway of the Vakhsh River approximately 
5 km downstream of the Baipaza Hydro Power Station (BHPS) in 
Khatlon Region, southern Tajikistan. As a consequence, the water 
level rose by about 7 meters (m), threatening to flood the BHPS. 
Also, generation of power and supply of water for irrigation was 
disrupted.  The  Government  took  the  immediate  measure  of 
blasting the landslide materials from the river to avoid flooding the 
BHPS. Since the first movement of 3 March, the landslide has 
been  moving  at  speeds  varying  between  a  few  millimeters  to 
1 centimeter a day. There is an imminent danger that sudden 
movement of the landslide will completely block the river thus 
submerging the BHPS. The Project aims to restore reliable water 
flows and initiate disaster prevention measures by (i) minimizing 
the occurrence and the magnitude of the landslide, (ii) mitigating 
its impact on the flow of the Vaskhsh River and its blockage, and 
(iii) studying a long-term solution.  
 
Rationale  Maintaining reliable water flows in the Vakhsh River is vital for 
Tajikistan  and  the  downstream  countries  of  Uzbekistan  and 
Turkmenistan. Any blockage of the Vakhsh River would disrupt 
the  generation  of  the  Vakhsh  River  cascade  comprising  five 
hydropower stations totaling 3,858 megawatts (MW) of installed 
generation or 90% of total generation capacity of the country. 
In the worst case, 90% of the electricity generating capacity of 
Tajikistan could be at risk. In addition, blockage of the Vakhsh 
River would endanger the water supply to downstream users for 
agriculture, industry, and drinking water. This would affect people 
in  the  Khatlon  Region,  and  would  disrupt  water  supply  to 
Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan. Further, a sudden breach of any 
landslide dam would pose a threat to downstream communities, 
installations, and infrastructure.

Objectives and Scope  The primary objective of the Project is to restore water flows in the 
Vakhsh River to at least the pre-earthquake levels and to initiate 
disaster prevention measures. This will be done by limiting the 
occurrence  and  magnitude  of  the  landslide  and  mitigating  its 
impact. The Project will: 
(i) part A:  carry out emergency slope stabilization measures to 
reduce the threat posed by the landslide and assist in disaster 
preparedness through observational and monitoring systems and 
earth-moving plant for river clearing operations; and 
(ii) part B: undertake a feasibility study to determine the most 
cost-effective long-term solution to the problem.

$2.40 million (36%) is the foreign exchange cost and $4.25 million 
equivalent  (64%)  the  local  currency  cost.  The  cost  estimate 
includes  physical  and  price  contingencies,  and  $0.7  million 
equivalent for taxes and duties.

(iii) monitoring and evaluation of project progress and impacts, 
and (iv) preparation of reports and communications with ADB. The 
PIU is staffed by local experts supported by domestic consultants. 
Provision has also been made for an international consultant to 
provide assistance and training in the design and execution of the 
emergency works. 
   
Procurement  The  Project  will  finance  civil  works,  materials,  machinery  and 
equipment,  and  technical  assistance.  Procurement  will  be  in 
accordance with the ADB's Guidelines for Procurement. Mainly 
force account and local competitive bidding will be used for civil 
works, with some minor works to be awarded on direct selection 
basis, taking into account the urgency of such works and the small 
amount of each contract. Purchase of equipment will be based on 
international shopping procedures. Advance procurement action 
has been approved, with retroactive financing from 14 April 2002 
up to a ceiling of $800,000 equivalent. 
   
Consulting Services  Part  A:  A  total  of  61  person-months  of  individual  domestic 
consulting services will be required to help implement emergency 
works  and  procurement.  Qualified  and  experienced  domestic

works, and will be responsible for survey investigations, detailed

Project Benefits and  The project components are designed to reduce the risk that the 
 Beneficiaries  landslide  will  block  the  flow  through  the  Vakhsh  River. 
Beneficiaries of the project will include electricity consumers and 
industrial,  agricultural,  and  potable  water  users  downstream. 
The potential losses that the Project aims to avoid are estimated 
as follows: 
 
  (i)  $20  million  for  the  repair  of  the  BHPS  and  about 
$40 million in lost power generation, 
(ii)  loss of production of the aluminum smelter plant, 
(iii)  significant  lost  agricultural  production  from  173,000 
hectares (ha) of irrigated land, and 
(iv)  loss of potable water supply to around 650,000 people 
living in nine regions dependent on the Vakhsh River flow. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  Prolonged heavy rain or a strong earthquake would pose a risk to 
the implementation and performance of the emergency works, 
primarily  by  triggering  another  large  landslide.  This  risk  could 
impact on the investment, the scheduling of the works, and the 
safety of personnel and plant. Other risks include nonperformance 
of  the  Ministry  of  Energy  and  Barki  Tajik  and  its  contractors. 
Furthermore,  there  could  be  some  risk  of  regional  political 
instability, though this is considered to be low.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of Tajikistan for the Emergency Baipaza Landslide Stabilization Project.  
 
II.  RATIONALE 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  Maintaining  reliable  water  flows  in  the  Vakhsh  River  is  vital  for  Tajikistan  and  the 
downstream countries of Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan. Any blockage of the Vakhsh River 
would disrupt the generation of the Vakhsh River cascade comprising five hydropower stations 
totaling 3,858 megawatts (MW) of installed generation or 90% of total generation capacity of the 
country. In the worst case, 90% of the electricity generating capacity of Tajikistan could be at 
risk. In addition, blockage of the Vakhsh River would endanger the water supply to downstream 
users for agriculture, industry, and drinking water.  This would affect people in the Khatlon 
Region, and would disrupt water supply to Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan. A sudden breach of 
any  landslide  dam  would  pose  a  threat  to  downstream  communities,  installations,  and 
infrastructure. 
 
3.  Hydropower is the major source of energy in Tajikistan and plays an important role in the 
national economy. It accounts for well over 90% of the energy supply. Tajikistan's power system 
comprises three separate power grids, the north, south and the Gorno-Badakhshan systems, 
which are operated by Barki Tajik. The installed generation capacity totals 4,354 megawatts 
(MW), including 4,000 MW of hydropower capacity. Out of this, the Cascade River plants of the 
Vakhsh River represent 3,858 MW. In summer time, Tajikistan has on average an energy 
surplus of about 4,200 gigawatts (GWh), which is exported mainly to Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan 
and Uzbekistan. In wintertime, Tajikistan imports electricity from Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan 
to meet the energy demand mainly for heating. All major hydropower plants are on the Vakhsh 
River. Nurek Hydropower station (NHPS) with 3,000 MW of installed capacity is the largest in 
Central Asia and generates electricity throughout the year. It was constructed in stages from 
1962 to 1979, and regulates the Vakhsh River flow, on a seasonal basis, for irrigation needs of 
the Amu Darya basin countries (Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan) during the growing season (May 
to July). Baipaza Hydro Power Station (BPHS), located 35 kilometers (km) downstream of 
NHPS, regulates the river flow on a daily basis and has a capacity of 600 MW. BHPS has been 
in operation since 1985. The Baipaza reservoir is used for water supply and irrigation purposes 
of nine regions with irrigated area of around 173,000 ha.1 This region covers most of the area 
south of Dushanbe, which has a population of more than 2 million and has been identified by 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) as a poor region under the ongoing power rehabilitation project 
loan.2

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
4.  Analysis.  On  3  March  2002  at  4:10  pm,  Tajikistan  experienced  an  earthquake  of 
magnitude 7.4 on the Richter scale and with its epicenter in Afghanistan. The earthquake 
triggered a mass of earth and rocks to slide into the Vakhsh River 5 km downstream of BHPS 
on the Vakhsh River in Khatlon Region. The first landslide partly blocked the narrow waterway 
of the Vakhsh River, causing the water level at the landslide to rise by 7 meters (m), and 
threatening to flood upstream BHPS. The heavy rains that followed the landslide in early March 
worsened this. Flows to the Pravaya-Vetka main canal assisted under an ADB emergency 
loan,3 could be affected by such an event. This canal is fed through a tunnel that takes water in 
from the reservoir of BHPS and provides irrigation supplies to 26,000 ha and provides potable 
water to 220,000 people in three districts. Since the first movement on 3 March 2002, the 
landslide has been moving at speeds varying from a few millimeters to 1 centimeter per day. A 
more detailed description of the landslide is given in Appendix 1. 
 
5.  To allow the river channel to be cleared sufficiently to enable the free flow of water, the 
BHPS had to be stopped during the day and operated only partially during the night. Explosives 
were used to remove the natural dam, and from 12 April to 22 April the BHPS was operated at 
half capacity, releasing water only for the minimum of irrigation requirements downstream. A 
further cessation of operation will be necessary to allow additional widening of the riverbed at 
the landslide location, in order to decrease the water level at the BHPS by a further 2 m.  
 
6.  The immediate and direct impact of future river blockages will be the disruption of power 
generation  in  Tajikistan  and  water  supply  for  Tajikistan,  Turkmenistan,  and  Uzbekistan, 
including for irrigation of around 173,000 ha. NHPS, as the largest hydropower station of the 
Central  Asian  Electric  System,  is  a  significant  contributor  to  the  region's  load-frequency 
regulation. Should the Vakhsh River become blocked, the NHPS will have to cease operation 
temporarily, and the stability of the whole Central Asian System may suffer. In addition, the 
BHPS would be submerged and severely damaged by flooding. 
 
7.  The indirect impact will be the stoppage of aluminum production, which is highly energy 
dependent. Tajik Aluminum Smelter (TADAZ), the government-owned aluminum smelter, is one 
of the largest industrial users of electricity and had a demand of about 600 MW in 2002. The 
hydropower plant of Nurek directly supplies the TADAZ factory. This factory, with a capacity 
estimated  at  390,000  tons  per  year,  exports  almost  the  entire  aluminum  production, 
predominantly  to  the  Netherlands  (49%),  Turkey  (19%),  Belgium  (13%),  and  Iran  (6%).  A 
blocking of the Vakhsh River would therefore drastically reduce foreign currency revenues for 
Tajikistan. 
 
8.  Finally, if a river blockage were to occur and could not be removed quickly, then, in the 
worst case outcome, the resultant dam could eventually breach catastrophically, resulting in 
downstream flooding and damage to livelihoods, power generation, and water supply. 
 
9.  At  the  request  of  the  Government,  ADB  staff  joined  on  6  April  2002  the  site  visit 
organized by the Tajik Prime Minister and comprising heads of diplomatic missions, senior 
representatives of the United Nations (UN), and international financial institutions based in 
Tajikistan.  On  18  April  2002,  the  Government  sent  a  formal  request  to  ADB  for  urgent

10.  The  Government  acted  quickly  to  assess  the  extent  of  the  damage,  implement

necessary rehabilitation works to restore the reliability of water flow in the river in the Baipaza

11.  The emergency rehabilitation measures are required to reduce the risk posed by the 
Baipaza landslide and to  confirm the most cost-effective long-term solution. The combination of 
emergency measures and disaster preparedness is considered  the best response to address 
the landslide. For a long-term solution, a number of alternatives may be considered, including 
further improvements to slope stability and river management options that include the relief 
tunnel already proposed. Such ADB assistance to the Government would be in line with ADB's 
policy on emergency operations as it will (i) avoid diverting the Government's development 
resources  to  address  this  natural  calamity,  (ii)  prevent  the  potentially  catastrophic 
consequences of the still moving landslide,5 (iii) restore the full generating capacity of the BHPS 
as well as the previous water flows of the Vaskhsh River, (iv) increase the reliability of power 
and water irrigation supplies, (v) involve simple solutions that do not require a long preparation 
period, (vi) have the full support of the Government through its participation in the steering 
committee,  and  (vii)  help  evolve  an  effective  long-term  strategy  to  mitigate/eliminate  the 
landslide impact . 
 
12.  Lessons Incorporated. The lessons learned from a number of emergency projects 
financed by ADB have been incorporated in the project design. Of particular relevance are the 
Emergency Flood Rehabilitation Project (EFRP)6 and the Emergency Restoration of Yavan 
Water Conveyance System Project (ERYWCSP),7 which are the two emergency loans financed 
by ADB in Tajikistan and are performing creditably. Involvement of the Government in these 
projects has been important for their success. A similar degree of Government involvement has 
been built into the present project. Under the Power Rehabilitation Project approved in 2000, 
project implementation has been slower than anticipated. There is a delay of about one year in 
recruitment  of  the  project  implementation  consultants  due  to  the  executing  agency’s 
unfamiliarity with ADB procedures, possibly on account of being a first-time borrower of a loan 
from ADB. To avoid similar problems under this Project, the same executing agency as under 
the Power Rehabilitation Project will act as the implementing agency for this Project. The 
Project will use the same core project implementation unit (PIU) as for the Power Rehabilitation 
Project, with staff that has been trained in ADB's procedures and guidelines. Imprest account 
procedures with initial deposit and simplified procurement procedures being proposed under this 
Project will mitigate the risk of delays in implementation of the Project.

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.   Objectives 
 
13.  The strategic objective is to avoid severe disruptions to the economic development of 
Tajikistan and to the Government's poverty reduction program, which could arise from  further 
deterioration in the condition of the landslide. The specific project objective is to restore water 
flows in the Vakhsh River to at least the preearthquake levels and initiate disaster prevention 
measures.  The  project  activities  will  limit  further  damage  from  the  Baipaza  landslide  and 
mitigate its impact on the flow of water in the Vakhsh River. The project framework is given in 
Appendix 2. 
 
B.  Components and Outputs 
14.  The Project has two parts, emergency slope stabilization and disaster preparedness, 
and study of a long-term solution for disaster prevention (details are in Appendix 3). 
 
1.  Part A:  Emergency Slope Stabilization and Disaster Preparedness 
15.  Part A is intended to minimize the immediate threat to the flow of the Vakhsh River. The 
investigation,  design,  procurement,  and  commissioning  of  a  long-term  solution  could  take 
several years to implement. Emergency measures are therefore needed to reduce the risk 
posed by the landslide during this period. This approach is proposed because it (i) recognizes 
the scale and complexity of the landslide problem; (ii) incorporates reasonable and necessary 
precautionary measures to reduce the rate and continuation of land slippage; and (iii) allows 
preparedness for the realistic worst case outcome should it arise during the implementation 
period. The two courses of action to achieve this are as follows (details shown in Appendix 4): 
 
16.  Slope Stabilization Measures. The stability of the slope will be improved to slow the 
rate of slippage. The proposed emergency rehabilitation measures comprise the following: 
 
(i)  improving and constructing access and haul roads to the site and to the proposed 
excavation spoil disposal locations (up to 30 km of access road), 
 
(ii)  cutting back and benching the slope immediately above the landslide to reduce load 
and remove material that might otherwise fail and aggravate stability conditions 
below (estimated 600,000  cubic meters [m3] of material), 
 
(iii)  draining the benched cut back and the natural slopes above the landslide, and in 
particular reducing subsurface seepage water entering the slide mass (2 km of 
drains), 
 
(iv)  removing slipped masses, wherever practicable and desirable, from the area below 
the current landslide to reduce load and remove material that would otherwise fail 
again and aggravate stability conditions below (200,000 m3), and 
 
(v)  draining the middle slope of the landslide.   
 
17.  The implementation of the above works requires the following activities:

5 
(i)  Survey and investigation will be required to confirm the details and quantities of the 
emergency works. The survey will comprise a topographic survey of the landslide, 
the areas to be cut back and removed, and the access to the spoil disposal sites. 
Part of this survey has been undertaken by Barki Tajik and the costs incurred since 
14  April  2002  have  been  incorporated  into  the  Project.  The  investigation  will 
comprise geological mapping, drilling, and trial pitting to define in more detail the 
mechanics of the landslide and to yield geotechnical data to finalize the design of 
earthworks. These investigations are limited to those required to advance the design 
and implementation of the emergency works. Engineering geological mapping is 
considered to be the most important of the investigation activities. 
 
(ii)  Design will comprise confirming earthworks slopes and other stability calculations, 
drainage configuration, and standard details; the detailed location and typical cross-
section of access roads; the layout and formation of spoil areas and the production of 
design drawings; general arrangement drawings; bills of quantities; specifications; 
bid documents; and contract documentation. 
 
(iii)  Road construction and improvement will comprise improving existing tracks to 
allow access to the site and to spoil areas for earth moving plant and vehicles.  
In most cases, a four-wheel drive track already exists, but to hasten the works, a new 
road will be needed from the top of the landslide to the spoil areas, in order to 
decrease haulage distances. 
 
(iv)  Earthworks  will  comprise  a  benched  cut-back  at  the  head  of  the  landslide  to 
improve overall stability in that area and reduce potential volumes of failure. An 
outline design has already been prepared by Barki Tajik. Earthworks will also include 
the selected removal of landslipped masses from beneath the back scar. 
 
(v)  Drainage is a key element in the stability of the entire slope and it is important that 
steps are taken wherever practicable to prevent water from entering the landslide 
mass in the first place. Lines of concentrated subsurface flow have been identified 
and these will require excavation and discharge away from the landslide. Two types 
of drain are proposed: (a) a conventional French drain with perforated plastic pipe, 
filter material, and backfill; and (b) a deeper open trench drain with impermeable 
invert. 
 
18.  The above activities will be carried out under the management of the Barki Tajik PIU and 
assisted by a team of domestic consultants. The Project implementation support component will 
provide  inputs  for  surveys,  investigation,  design,  construction  supervision,  environmental 
monitoring, and social impact assessment. The PIU will implement the Project. The PIU will be 
supported by 61 person-months of individual domestic consultant input.  
 
19.  An individual international consultant will be assigned during the early stages of the 
implementation  to  confirm  the  design  and  guide  the  implementation  of  the  works.  This  is 
considered to be essential given the high-risk circumstances and relative inexperience of Barki 
Tajik, local consultants, and local contractors in dealing with problems of this nature and scale. 
Four person-months of foreign expert time have been set aside to cover this on-the-job training 
activity. 
 
20.  Disaster Preparedness Measures. Because the slope may still fail due to heavy rain or 
an earthquake, improvements in disaster preparedness will allow the Tajikistan authorities to

6 
respond more quickly and effectively if the river is blocked again during the implementation 
period. These measures comprise the following elements: 
 
(i)  Rainfall will be monitored and the visual, survey, and photographic monitoring of 
the slope will continue. The rain gauge will be an automatic, continuously recording 
device installed at the BHPS. It will allow recorded and observed movements to be 
compared against recorded rainfall conditions.  
(ii)  Equipment and materials will be provided to allow the Tajikistan authorities to act 
as quickly as possible to restore flow in the Vakhsh River, were it to become 
blocked or severely restricted by further movements of the Baipaza landslide during 
the implementation period.  
 
2.  Part B:  Feasibility Study 
 
21.  Part B will evaluate the technical feasibility and financial and economic viability of the 
long-term solutions and options, including the construction of 1–2 river flow relief tunnels for 
bypassing the landslide.  
 
22.  The feasibility study is divided into three elements: 
 
(i)  The appropriateness of the preferred solution for the management of flow through 
the Vakhsh River at the Baipaza landslide will be confirmed, and an initial design 
made. 
 
(ii)  Landslide hazards in the Vakhsh River corridor will be mapped. Aerial photograph 
interpretation,  published  topographical  maps  and  geological  mapping  will  be 
combined to prepare a landslide location map for the Vakhsh Valley (both valley 
sides) at a scale of 1:10,000, from the BHPS to approximately 25 km downstream, 
as far as the Sangtudinskaya hydropower station. A summary assessment of all 
high hazard slopes in this study area will be prepared, and will include their likely 
effect on the flow in the Vakhsh River and the operation of the Baipaza and 
Sangtudinskaya hydropower stations. 
 
(iii)  Scope, terms of reference, and cost estimates will be prepared for the detailed 
design of the long-term solution.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits 
 
42.  The Project aims primarily to restore reliable water flows in the Vakhsh River. For this, 
the Project will minimize the risk posed by the Baipaza landslide to the flow of water in the 
Vakhsh River and consequently the operation of the BHPS. The Project will improve long-term 
stability  and  provide  long-term  remedial  measures,  while  at  the  same  time  equipping  the 
Government with plant, materials, and know-how to deal with and monitor landslide movements 
in the short term. The Project will also supplement the Tajik skills in landslide studies and 
planning for landslides. 
 
43.  The Project benefits are savings in lost output that would result from the landslide if it 
fails. Potential losses that may be incurred if the Project is not implemented are estimated as 
follows: 
 
(i)  lost generation of $40 million, taking into account an unavailability of 24 hours for 
the whole Vaskhsh River Cascade and an unavailability of 2 years for the BHPS as 
a result of submersion; 
 
(ii)  cost of $20 million for rehabilitating the BHPS after flooding, taking into account that 
25% to 30% of the electromechanical equipment might have to be rehabilitated; 
 
(iii)  loss of revenue from TADAZ; 
 
(iv)  losses in irrigated agriculture (the Vaskhsh River irrigates 66% of the cotton fields 
of Tajikistan); and 
 
(v)  social losses as a result of disruption of potable water supply. 
 
B.  Social, Environmental, and Economic Impacts 
 
44.  The  Government  and  Barki  Tajik  have  agreed  to  put  in  place  all  necessary 
environmental protection and to carry out the works in accordance with the environmental law 
and regulations of Tajikistan and ADB’s environmental guidelines. They have also agreed, and 
provision has been made, for staff of the Ministry of Environment to be involved as advisers and 
observers  in  the  design  and  implementation  of  the  works  and  the  monitoring  of  any 
environmental effects.

12 
45.  A  summary  initial  environmental  examination  was  undertaken  and  is  presented  in 
Appendix  10.  All  potential  impacts  identified  can  be  avoided/mitigated  by  design  and  by 
construction planning and supervision. The environmental condition at the site can be further 
confirmed  by  staff  of  the  Ministry  of  Environment.  The  findings  indicate  that  the  negative 
environmental impacts of the Project can be mitigated to an acceptable level. Hence the Project 
is classified as environmental category B, which does not require a full-scale environmental 
impact assessment. 
 
46.  No negative impact will persist during the operation phase. Moreover, positive impacts 
can be envisaged through the restoration of water flow in the Vakhsh River and potentially 
through a longer term decrease in suspended solids and sediments. 
 
47.  Blockage of the Vakhsh River has distinct negative consequences downstream for the 
livelihoods of large populations, industry, and the economy. Regardless of the details of the final 
solution that is selected, the Project will help improve management of the Vakhsh River flow at 
Baipaza, and hence have positive social, environmental, and economic impacts. 
 
48.  The Project will not involve resettlement or land acquisition. The spoil areas are not used 
for agriculture or habitation and are state property. The Baipaza landslide area cannot be 
returned to productive land use in the foreseeable future. Improvements to the flow of water in 
Vakhsh River, however, have major positive implications for land use and water abstraction 
downstream. The Project has the overall aim of eventually improving the flow of water in the 
Vakhsh River, which will benefit agriculture and water supply downstream. A summary poverty 
reduction and social strategy is given in Appendix 11. 
 
49.  No human settlements are in the immediate vicinity of the landslide and therefore there 
are  no  resettlement  issues.  There  is  no  major  expropriation  of  agricultural  or  otherwise 
economic land, and no obvious impacts on ecology. The only issue identified relates to the likely 
continued use of explosives to clear the river immediately after landslide movement takes place, 
and this has some negative implications, most significantly geotechnical. The construction of 
access roads and the development of spoil disposal areas may have some physical effects, but 
Barki Tajik confirms the readiness to minimize these. 
 
C.  Risks 
 
50.  Nature Risk. A large rainstorm or prolonged period of heavy rain could be a significant 
hazard  to  the  progress  of  the  Project  and  its  applicability  given  the  new  slope  condition. 
Furthermore, an earthquake of significant intensity would endanger the progress of the Project. 
The project design, through advance fast-track procurement procedures, an imprest fund with 
retroactive facilities, and disbursement facilities, will allow the completion of most of the initial 
activities before the start of  the next wet season in November 2002. 
 
51.  Political Risk. The Project is near Dushanbe where the social and political situation is 
calmer than in other parts of Tajikistan. The political risk during Project implementation is hence 
limited also because of the short duration of the Project, which is about 20 months. The 
Government involvement, through its participation at a highest level in the steering committee of 
the Project, will largely mitigate the political risk. The quick measures taken by the Government 
under the Project will enhance political stability in Tajikistan. 
 
52.  Project Delay. Project could be delayed due to the (i) nature of the works, (ii) inability of 
contractors  to  meet  quality  and  schedule,  and  (iii)  inexperience  of  Barki  Tajik  with  ADB's

monitoring of implementation progress by the PIU and the steering committee, and regular ADB 
review missions. Advance procurement action, adoption of international shopping, and local 
competitive bidding will largely reduce the risk of delayed procurement. 
 
53.  Cost Overrun. Cost overruns could occur due to uncertainties in the precise scope and 
quantities of work. However, this is expected to be manageable, given that substantial physical

THE BAIPAZA LANDSLIDE 
 
 
 
1.  On 3 March 2002, an earthquake triggered a landslide 5 kilometers (km) downstream of 
the Baipaza Hydro Power Station (BHPS). This was the second earthquake (the first was in 
1992) at this location since the commissioning of the BHPS in 1986, although the first recorded 
failure took place in 1968, before the BHPS was constructed. In March 1968 the landslide 
comprised 25–30 million cubic meters (m3) of material and the river was blocked for 2 weeks to 
an elevation of 600 meters (m) upstream of the landslide dam (the current water level is 
approximately 565–570 m and the elevation of the turbine hall at the BHPS is 581.5 m). In May 
1992, the level of the water upstream of the landslide rose to 580 m. The March 2002 landslide 
resulted in a 5 m high natural dam causing a water level rise to 572 m at the landslide and an 
increase in water level of 7–8 m at the BHPS.  
 
2.  The landslide is part of an area of ancient (probably immediately post-glacial) deep-seated 
failure involving the entire valley side. The Baipaza landslide is approximately 1,800 m in length 
and 800 m wide at its widest part, alongside the River Vakhsh. The landslide has a shape and 
mechanism of movement similar to an egg timer. The upper part is a wide source area of failing 
ground whereby large masses of slope are detached progressively. These masses rapidly find 
their way through the narrow throat of the landslide and are deposited onto a large colluvial mass 
of material that forms the entire lower slope adjacent to the river. The depth of this mass is about 
30–40  m.  Slippage  is  continuing  due  to  loading  from  failing  materials  and  the  build  up  of 
groundwater during the wet season. Due to the control of flow in the river by the upstream power 
stations (Baipaza and Nurek), river scour of the toe of the slope is unlikely to be as severe as it 
might otherwise have been prior to construction of the installations.  
 
3.  The total volume of the landslide is unknown, but is estimated by Barki Tajik to be  
5 million to 25 million m3. The Mission’s observations suggest that the landslide might be of the 
order of 7 million to10 million m3. The current speed of landslide movement is estimated to be in 
the range of 0.7 to 1.0 centimeter (cm) per day, which is a dry season rate, and rates of 
movement in the forthcoming wet season are anticipated to be much higher. 
 
4.  It  is  impossible  to  say  when  and  to  what  extent  the  next  failure  will  occur.  Slope 
movement will be governed significantly by the rainfall pattern and the timing and magnitude of 
seismic activity. The failure of approximately 350,000 m3 is imminent in the mudslide at the 
northern end of the landslide adjacent to the river. If only a third of this material reaches the 
waterway, it could block the river to a similar depth as the slide in 1968 (30 m). Such a failure 
could also activate a much larger unstable area immediately upslope with a volume approaching 
1 million m3 or more. All of this material is not likely to be deposited in the river instantaneously. 
If the rainfall conditions over the next few years remain low to moderate, and the area is not 
affected by any significant seismic or blasting activity, then slope failures during the short term 
could  be  relatively  small,  especially  if  the  proposed  works  at  the  top  of  the  slide  are 
implemented rapidly and effectively. However, the future behavior of the landslide, even over  
1–3 years cannot be predicted with any certainty, and a large failure could occur. Therefore, the 
monitoring of movements on the slide should be expanded and extended to record the details of 
movements during the forthcoming and following wet seasons and a rain gauge should be 
established this dry season at the BHPS to compare movements against recorded rainfall.

through the Baipaza Landslide Area, Republic of Tajikistan 
 
 
A.  Background 
 
1.  The Baipaza Landslide is approximately 60 kilometers (km) southeast of Dushanbe the 
capital.  The  landslide  was  reactivated  following  the  earthquake  of  3  March  2002.  This 
earthquake had its epicenter in Afghanistan and was measured there at 7.4 on the Richter 
scale. Heavy rain also occurred in the Baipaza area during March and April 2002, and this 
served to reduce the stability of the slope further. The Baipaza landslide forms part of an area of 
ancient  landslides  occupying  the  western  valley  side  of  the  Vakhsh  River,  and  recorded 
reactivated movements at Baipaza have occurred in 1968, 1992, and 2002. The river below has 
been temporarily blocked or partly blocked on all three occasions. The Baipaza Hydro Power 
Station (BHPS) is on the Vakhsh River approximately 5 km upstream of the landslide. The 
March  2002  slope  movements  temporarily  blocked  the  river,  thus  disturbing  the  normal 
operation of the BHPS. Landslide debris was removed from the restricted river channel by 
blasting, but the channel remains narrow and further landslide movements will create operating 
problems for the power station and in the worst case could submerge it. Together, the Baipaza 
and  the  Nurek  hydropower  stations,  further  upstream,  produce  90%  of  the  total  electricity 
production in Tajikistan. Furthermore, blockage or otherwise restricted flow in the Vakhsh River 
has significant implications for water resources and water abstraction downstream, where an 
estimated 650,000 people depend partly or fully on the Vakhsh River for water supply. The 
development of a cost-effective and sustainable solution is therefore imperative.

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION 
 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The Baipaza landslide project is on the Vakhsh River in southern Tajikistan. Landslide 
movements have blocked the river on three occasions in the recent past and on the last two 
occasions (1992 and 2002) this has given rise to disruption of hydro power generation at the 
Baipaza Hydro Power Station (BHPS) location upstream. In addition, the Vakhsh River is critical 
to the supply of irrigation and potable water over a large area downstream, covering three 
regions of Tajikistan and neighboring countries.  
 
2.  The Baipaza landslide is approximately 1.8 kilometers (km) long and 0.8 km wide. The 
purpose of the Project is to reduce the risk posed by the landslide to the flow of water in the 
Vakhsh River, thus enabling more efficient power generation at BHPS and the maintenance of 
flow in the Vakhsh River for the benefit of downstream users. 
 
3.  An initial environmental examination (IEE) was undertaken during the appraisal mission 
in June 2002 and the findings are presented hereafter. The mission visited the Baipaza site and 
held discussions with Tajik government agencies, local government representatives, Barki Tajik 
(the  state  power  company)  representatives,  and  the  Ministry  of  Environment.  The  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  classified  the  Baipaza  landslide  project  as  environmental  
category B.  
 
B.  Description of the Project 
 
4.  The description of the project is given in paragraphs 14 to 23 of the main text. 
 
C.  Description of the Environment 
 
1.  Physical Resources 
 
5.  The  Baipaza  landslide  is  on  the  western  valley  side  of  the  Vakhsh  River,  5  km 
downstream of the BHPS. The Vakhsh River is a major tributary of the Pyenj River and is 
orientated approximately north to south. The underlying geology comprises limestones, marls, 
gypsums, and clays, overlain by thick loess soils and colluvium and there is evidence that 
widespread deep-seated landslides have occurred in pre-historic times on the slopes occupied 
by the Baipaza landslide and immediately to the north. The area is seismically highly active.  
A large earthquake with an epicenter in neighboring Afghanistan triggered the failure of the 
slope in March 2002.  
 
6.  The climate is Continental, characterized by cold winters and warm-hot summers. The 
wet season is between November and April and average annual rainfall is about 600–800 
millimeters, though there are no raingauges within 10 km of the site. 
 
7.  The  Baipaza  landslide  site  is  accessed  only  via  tracks  from  the  north  and  west. 
Numerous tracks in the area once provided access for farm tractors. 
 
  2.  Ecological Resources 
 
8.  Tajikistan  is  a  center  of  biological  diversity.  However,  half  a  century  of  resource 
depletion and exploitation focusing on hydropower and cotton has resulted in drastic alteration 
of habitats, and large losses in terrestrial and aquatic biodiversity. The Tiger Bulk Reserve is

  3.  Human and Economic Development  
 
9.  The immediate area was evacuated in the 1940s when a landslide on an adjacent slope 
resulted in two fatalities. Since then some villagers have returned to the area, but none have 
relocated in the immediate area of the Baipaza landslide.  
 
10.  Generally, the upper valley side slopes are gently undulating while the middle and lower 
slopes are steeply inclined. This pattern is most pronounced on the slopes occupied by the 
landslide and the area to the south of it. The upper slopes are well drained and suitable for the 
cultivation of wheat. In fact, local accounts suggest that the area was an important wheat 
growing area in previous years. Presently, most of the cultivable land is dedicated to hay and 
fodder for cattle.  
 
11.  Most of the area around the Baipaza landslide is covered with grass. The landscape is 
without trees.  A water supply pipe was previously operational along the ridge top above the 
Baipaza landslide, but is no longer functional  and has been vandalized. 
 
12.  The only industry evident in the area is the salt extraction and processing plant to the 
northwest. This plant extracted brine from deep groundwater for processing but now appears to 
be not functioning.

13.  Very few people live within the vicinity of the landslide.

D.  Institutional Requirements and Environmental Monitoring Program 
 
15.  The Government and the Ministry of Energy (MOE) have agreed to put in place all 
necessary  environmental  protection  and  to  carry  out  the  works  in  accordance  with  the 
environmental legislation of Tajikistan. They have also agreed, and provision has been made, 
for staff of the Ministry of Environment to be involved as advisers and observers in the design 
and implementation of the works and the monitoring of any environmental effects. 
 
E.  Findings And Recommendations 
 
16.  The contractor will need to establish an operational safety plan, and to demonstrate 
compliance  with  international  safety  standards  required  for  the  operation  of  a  potentially 
hazardous site. In addition, MOE will report on a regular basis on environmental management 
and implementation of the mitigating measures in the spoil area and the slope protection. 
 
17.  Considering the urgency of processing the emergency loan Project, it is recommended 
that this report will suffice as both the IEE and summary IEE report. All potential impacts 
identified can be avoided/mitigated by design and by construction planning and supervision. 
Further confirmation of the environmental condition at the site can be undertaken by staff of the 
Ministry of Environment. 
 
18.  The findings indicate that the negative environmental impacts of the Project can be 
mitigated to an acceptable level. Hence it is recommended that the project be classified as 
environmental  category  B,  which  does  not  require  a  full-scale  environmental  impact 
assessment. 
 
19.  No negative impact will persist during operation phase. Moreover, positive impacts can 
be envisaged through the restoration of water flow in the Vakhsh River and potentially through a 
longer term decrease in suspended solids and sediments.  
 
20.  The Project will not involve resettlement or land acquisition. 
 
F.  Conclusions 
 
21.  As the adverse environmental consequences resulting from the Project can be mitigated 
to  an  acceptable  level,  and  the  other  technical  alternatives  to  address  the  objectives  are 
apparently feasible, this IEE and summary SIEE report is recommended to be sufficient. Further 
environmental impact assessment is not required. 
 
22.  An environmental monitoring plan should however be established to ensure that all 
dispositions will be and have been taken for mitigating the adverse impacts. 
 
23.  A  program  should  be  established  under  the  Project,  to  address  the  environmental 
awareness,  mitigation,  monitoring,  and  financing  issues  in  a  manner  acceptable  for  an 
emergency project.

B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                        Proposed Classification: Other 
Analysis: 
The Project concerns the restoration of reliable water flow of the Vaskhsh River, which is used for power 
generation (90% of the total generation of the country), water supply for the Khatlon Region (identified as 
a poor region), and for irrigation purposes of nine regions. Out of 6 million of Tajikistan’s population,  
83% are below the poverty line. A blockage of the river will have catastrophic consequences on  
(i) the supply of electricity (import of electricity costs more than 10 times the generation costs);  
(ii) the agriculture, as the Khatlon Region is highly productive in cotton (main resources of foreign 
exchange for the country), and (iii) the water supply. In such circumstances, the poor will not have any 
access to electricity and water. A lack of irrigation will lead to more unemployment as agriculture 
represents (in 2000) around 60% of the total employment in the country.  
The Project, by restoring the water flow of the river, will enable power generation to fuller capacity, and 
secure water supply and irrigation for agricultural needs of this part of Tajikistan.
